Award.AwardTitle: Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site - Training and Research Experiences in Nonlinear Dynamics (TREND)
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the Training and Research Experiences in Nonlinear Dynamics (TREND) REU Site at the University of Maryland. The main goal of the program is to involve undergraduate students in frontier research on nonlinear dynamics. The program is also aimed at helping undergraduate students prepare for graduate school, and for research and teaching positions throughout industry and academia. The program will involve approximately 10 students who will spend 11 weeks in the summer on campus involved in research. Examples of possible theoretical and experimental research topics include: nanophotonic devices, spatio-temporal chaos and synchronism of chaotic systems, chaotic microwave circuits, granular media, development of singularities in fluids and solids, nonlinear dynamics in optical systems and charged particle beams, magnetic reconnection, and turbulence and nonlinear phenomena in plasmas. Seminar series will complement and reinforce the learning experience. Student projects and presentations will be judged on the final day of the program, and winners will be funded to present their work at a national conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The TREND program ran for nine years in the Institute for Research in Electronics and Applied Physics at the University of Maryland, College Park. The main goal of our program was to involve undergraduate students in frontier research on nonlinear dynamics. The program also helped students prepare for graduate school, and for research and teaching positions throughout industry and academia.  This training came as a result of their research topic, technical and professional seminar series (over a dozen talks each summer), student field trips, and their informal contact with other members of the program. Over a dozen faculty and more than two dozen post-docs and graduate students participated in the training of the TREND students. Over the 9-year program span, essentially 50% of the participants came from underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines and about one-quarter came from universities or colleges that don't have Ph. D. Programs in Physics. Most of the students were not from the University of Maryland. Forty-five women in all were trained in our program out of 95 total participants! Every year the program terminated in the “TREND FAIR” where guests from inside and outside the university were invited to attend and hear and see the products of the student research. Each year, the students whose projects were voted most outstanding were sent to professional conferences to present their work. The TREND program resulted in over 30 technical presentations and publications in addition to four invited talks.

More information regarding this program can be found at:

www.ireap.umd.edu/TREND
